Award.AwardTitle: NSF Student Travel Grant for 2015 ACM Conference on Embedded Networked Sensor Systems (ACM SenSys)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
ACM Sensys conference is the leading international conference on wireless sensor networks and systems. It invites research contributions addressing the challenges in the area of wireless sensor systems, algorithms, and applications. The conference features a high-quality technical program, with an acceptance rate of around 10% out of around 250 submissions. It has a single-track session, which offers significant opportunities for individual and small groups that foster technical and social interactions among a diverse set of participants.

This award will help increase the representation and participation of United States-based students at the conference by providing 15 or more travel grants limited to a maximum of $1500 each. By creating new opportunities for graduate students, especially those from under-represented groups, to attend a high-quality conference, this award will benefit the students by giving them an opportunity to interact with world-class researchers, inspire them to try new research directions, providing mentoring opportunities, as well as the chance to seek out internships and post-doctoral positions which will help the students advance in their research career.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The support from NSF for Student Travel Grant for 2015 ACM Conference on Embedded Networked Sensor Systems (ACM SenSys) have led to a success in supporting students to attend the prestigious conference in the field of sensor-enabled smart systems, as well as in helping them engaged in cutting-edge technology and research advances in the field.

SenSys has been very successful in creating bold academic progress in the field of sensor-enabled smart systems. Smart sensors are regarded as key technologies in revolutionizing a wide array of application areas, and thus requiring significant cross-disciplinary works from a variety of fields, including wireless communications, embedded systems, distributed systems, and data management. In the SenSys 2015 conference, we brought together academic, industry, and government professionals to this single-track, highly selective forum, and provided an ideal venue for ones pursuing technological advances of such smart sensor systems.

We had 15 student awardees supported by the grant, including 4 female and 3 underrepresented minority students in institutions in the US. They attended the conference and participated in a variety of discussions to express their views, learning experiences, and impressions of the field, as well as asked questions on research directions. As well, they served as student volunteers at the conference, and their effort enabled smooth execution of the conference program, while not hurting the students’ engagement and experiences, through careful task assignment considering students’ interest and availability.
